title: Erdős Problem #700: GCD of n with Binomial Coefficients
description: Study f(n) = min_{1<k≤n/2} gcd(n, C(n,k)). When does f(n) = n/P(n)? Are there ∞ many n with f(n) > √n? Is f(n) ≪ n/(log n)^A? Known: f(pq) = p, f(p²) ≥ p. Open.

sections.title: Definitions
sections.summary: Largest/smallest prime factor, f(n) = min gcd(n, C(n,k)).

sections.title: Three Open Questions
sections.summary: Characterization, large values (f(n) > √n), upper bound conjecture.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős and Szekeres studied the function f(n) = min_{1<k≤n/2} gcd(n, C(n,k)), which measures how divisible n is by binomial coefficients. The function is well-understood for semiprimes (f(pq) = p) but its behavior for general composite numbers is mysterious.
overview.problemStatement: Three questions about f(n): (1) Which composite n satisfy f(n) = n/P(n)? (2) Do infinitely many composite n have f(n) > √n? (3) Is f(n) ≪_A n/(log n)^A for all A?
overview.proofStrategy: We axiomatize f(n), state the basic sandwich f(n) ∈ [p(n), n/P(n)], record exact values for semiprimes and n=30, and formalize all three open questions.
keyInsights: f(pq) = p = n/P(n) for semiprimes, providing the simplest exact computation
f(p²) ≥ p = √n shows Question 2 holds for prime squares
The upper bound conjecture f(n) ≪ n/(log n)^A would mean f is much smaller than n/P(n) for most n
The function connects binomial coefficient divisibility to prime factorization structure
n = 30 is a notable non-semiprime example with f(30) = 6 = 30/5

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #700 poses three questions about the minimum gcd of n with its binomial coefficients. The function is exactly computed for semiprimes but poorly understood in general, with all three questions remaining open.
conclusion.implications: Resolution would advance the arithmetic theory of binomial coefficients, connecting to Kummer's theorem on p-adic valuations, Pascal's triangle modular patterns, and the distribution of prime factors.
openQuestions: Which composite n beyond semiprimes and 30 satisfy f(n) = n/P(n)?
Are there composite n (not prime squares) with f(n) > √n?
Is f(n) ≪ n/(log n)^A for every fixed A > 0?
What is the typical order of magnitude of f(n) for random composite n?
